content: hi guys why lock here very excited with
what I have to show you today I was drawing inspiration from open lock and
dragon lock these are clips from 3d printed tiles different lines that you
can buy and the concept that they came up with was clips that existed in the
foundation of the tile in the body of it and that's how you hold them together so
I was thinking how can I apply that to a crafted tile and so we have cardboard
lock all right the key ingredient here is chipboard
this is graphics medium chipboard and I know I use this in every episode but
guys I've seen some of you substitute thinner materials like cereal box that's
okay but for this application it won't do you really do need to use the exact
product and that's because of its thickness and its sturdiness what gotta
have strength here it's 1/16 of an inch thick there's a link in the video
description below and if you use that exact link at no extra cost to you I get
a small kickback from Amazon easy and free way to support the channel if you
want to so anyway first cut a two and a half inch square should take three or
four passes with your knife it's pretty thick stuff then cut some 3/4 inch
squares you need four of them and with a little bit of white glue attach one to
each corner just the thin layer don't overdo it the chipboard drinks this
stuff up and it dries within minutes then cut a 1 inch square and glue it in
the middle like this note don't use hot glue here use white glue or maybe extra
strength glue stick you don't want to introduce extra thickness due to hot
glue now onto single corrugated cardboard
available from any packing box make your material square before you start
measuring and cutting then cut out with two and a half inch square
and apply corrugation cladding if you're new to the channel corrugation cladding
is just this thin black cardstock or construction paper cut a thin strip of
it and hot glue it around the square to cover up the corrugation and then again
using white glue attach the two pieces together this is the foundation of the
tile from here on out we finished the tile using the methods we've talked
about many times before but for sake of completeness I'll quickly go through it
it only took me about three and a half hours to make these eight tiles
including dry time and camera work foam board
this is Dollar Tree foam board the classic DM Scotty find it's great
because the paper peels so easily but if you don't have access to it and can only
get other brands of foam board rubbing alcohol will help the paper free up from
the foam cut a half inch wide strip peel the paper from one side and texturize it
as desired I score two rows of offset bricks with my knife and then follow the
scores with a mechanical pencil to widen them then a half inch wide strip of
chipboard and glue them together this is a wall segment
attach it to the foundation with a bead of hot glue make sure it's flush with
the edge of the foundation and standing up straight as it cools then in black
vomit with cheap acrylic craft paint while it's drying let's do the spaces
cereal box measure out a grid of one and a quarter inch squares and cut them out
you'll need four per tile then do the same again except a bit smaller at one
and an eighth of an inch again four per tile round off the corners a little bit
then hot glue a small one to a big one make sure the shiny side is down because
the raw side takes paint much better now take some dark gray craft paint and
use a kitchen sponge to apply it to all surfaces tiles and squares you're aiming
for about 80% coverage and the more paint you bleed off the sponge the finer
the speckle will be sort of like a granite look so do whatever you like
then again with a lighter gray sponge but much less maybe only 20% coverage
like this tiles and squares it's important to paint the squares like this
before attaching them because it allowed you to dab at an angle and get it all
those edges if they were glued up the tile already you wouldn't be able to get
down in between them and you'd have a lot of unpainted black recesses which
doesn't look as good then a plain brown gonna pick two or three bricks per wall
and just paint them Brown easy then hot glue the spaces to the tile and for the
ones that are adjacent to walls just chop off that excess quarter inch with
scissors again none of this is new if you're new to the channel check out the
first five episodes or episode 76 where I give some alternate shortcuts for
doing the walls and the spaces the clips themselves are just chipboard rectangles
now with some basic math you're probably thinking they should obviously be an
inch wide and one and a half inches long so that they fit in those micelles
perfectly but we need to accommodate some tolerance for manufacturing error
after all some of your slots are probably like 0.9 inches or 1.1 inches
depending on how good you are so what you should do is cut them to be 7/8 of
an inch wide instead of one inch and one and a quarter inch long instead of one
and a half inches this guarantees they'll always bottom out when inserted
and it allows for a little bit of lateral shifting to ensure that you can
line everything up perfectly once they're put on the table also I went
back later and clipped the corners to help make them easier to insert just
want to take a moment here and show you that lateral play that I was talking
about earlier because the clip isn't an inch wide it's something less than that
it's intentional because your tiles aren't gonna be perfect and this will
allow you to slide them so they meet up perfectly and account
that manufacturing error on emphasize again the importance of using white glue
for that sandwich in the bottom layer a hot glue no matter how well you apply it
no matter how fast you get it smushed on there we'll add some tiny amount of
height and that's a fatal mistake the whole reason this works is we know the
exact height of the clip matches the slot because that layer is the same
material and if the slot is any taller you won't have the friction between the
clip and the inside of the tile that's the whole reason that this works now
these are a little bit fussy putting together so you might consider
assembling entire rooms prior to running your game and that way as the party
enters a new room you just pull it out from under the table and throw it down
saves that awkward 45 seconds of having to put the clips in assemble the room in
real time so look at this crazy strong I can hold up this entire assembly by just
one tile wave it around no play and if that holds you know it's gonna hold just
fine sitting on a table clip on features same no surprise here it's the same form
factor foundation is still 1/4 inch tall the wall is still 1/4 inch thick by the
way please leave suggestions for new clip-on features in the comments below
because I'm fresh out and if you're new to the channel check out my backlog for
the clip-on feature episodes to see all the possibilities here also I'm on
patreon if you're interested and if you like those cardstock miniatures check
out episode 9 now suppose you've made a few hundred why lock tiles to retrofit
them you simply take the bottom of the foundation so this bit right here the
very first thing we did and then you glue that to the bottom of your existing
tile again with white glue and weigh it down while it dries these two tiles are
actually among the very first batch I ever made so we glue them on weighed it
down give it an hour to be sure and yes this is going to add to your overall
tile height a little bit but if you do it to all of them then that shouldn't
matter and yes you have to address painting them if you want to I mean from
3 feet it's on the bottom of the tile I don't think you can see it but the great
thing about the classic sponged dungeon stone scheme is that it's so chaotic
that it really hides these different layers of material as well especially at
3 feet away when you're at the table so I paint the edges black
and then sponge on the to graze that I originally used fur for the walls and it
does a pretty good job of blending it in now I rush this and I was sloppy with
the black ideally you would just be careful and get the black only on the
chipboard but you can see these these blend in pretty nicely what about other
tile styles maybe like other systems here's a black magic craft foam tile of
three by three just roughed out obviously not finished but the concept
is the same use chipboard to create symmetric
missiles on the bottom then glue on another three-inch slab to close them in
slots created ready for clips again these aren't finished but just as I
showed you a minute ago you could simply extend your paint scheme for the side
down on to the chipboard alright guys so that's the concept two things I just
want to stress again number one the material I know I'm giving you my
affiliate link and everything but I'm not trying to shill I really really
believe you've got to use the right material you can't substitute you got to
use that chipboard it's thick and it's sturdy and it just gets worse the other
thing is and I've said it several times but the white glue use white glue and
then something that I think I lucked out on because I didn't really have to do
but you saw it there at the end when I was retrofitting weigh them down as
you're building them stack them up put a book on it or a glass of water or
something stack it and and weigh it down while it's drying
that's important because it'll make sure that this the slot is as thin as
possible and again that's going to be key to success if you're gonna do this I
recommend you do two tiles so if you're retrofitting retrofit to tiles if you're
building new build to new tiles but don't build more finish them get them
totally done prove that it works and you've worked out all the nuances like
the weird like that the little things that I just mentioned make sure that you
you're ready to mass-produce because you don't want to make a big set of these
and then it's loose and the clip doesn't have friction and everything so make
sure you know what you're doing proof of concept build two tiles first work out
the nuances alright guys feel free to check out my patreon the tabletop
crafter is guild group on Facebook and the Wildlife's armory page on facebook I
am why lock thank you for joining me and I'll see you next time
for all you 3d printers out there don't
forget to check out heroes hoard where you can get true tiles models as well as
a ton of other excellent fantasy related scenery
